awd_titl_txt: TWC: SBES: Small: Modeling the Economics of Search-Engine Manipulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Many recent security attacks are financially motivated. Understanding how attackers monetize their activities is critical to combine technological, legal, and economic intervention to render certain classes of attacks unprofitable, and disincentivize miscreants from considering them.

Manipulation of social network and web search-engine results to promote illicit businesses is increasingly common. Rather than the product of isolated attackers, search-engine manipulation relies on collaboration between many distinct actors, ranging from individuals installing malware on end-systems, to miscreants funneling traffic in exchange for commissions on sales.

This project aims to quantitatively model the economic interactions between the actors behind search-engine manipulation, and to infer which intervention policies could raise the cost of carrying out these attacks.                                                                

We develop novel measurement methodologies to collect large amounts of field data, cross-reference our measurements with data from industry partners, and gather forensic evidence on compromised hosts that are unknowingly participating in attacks. This leads us to quantify various operational parameters (e.g., common malware families, common infrastructure components...), and use them to build economic models of search-engine manipulation attacks.                                     

Project outcomes include (1) identifying salient features that denote relationships between different entities participating in search-engine manipulation campaigns, (2) describing possible relationships between different types of illicit online trades, and (3) discovering points of failure in the attackers' infrastructure, that the defenders can try to exploit. More generally, this study will further refine our understanding of online crime economics, which will not only be useful to security researchers, but also to economists and criminologists.

por.por_cntn:
Research supported by this led to several scientific advances in our understanding of manipulation attacks on recommender systems, with a particular focus on search engines.

More specifically, our research demonstrated how abuse-supported businesses such as purveyors of unlicensed pharmaceutical drugs (e.g., prescription medicine) have been gradually shifting from spam (untargeted, therefore inefficient) to search-engine result manipulation. Conducting a four-year study of the phenomenon we discovered a steady rise in "search-redirection attacks" at the expense of forum spam. We also discovered which countermeasures appeared to have a long term effect. Surprisingly, the adoption, by most major browsers, of HTTPS-only search had the somewhat unexpected side effect to reduce the magnitude of these attacks -- due to the constraints on how the HTTP "Referer" field can be passed across domains, while using HTTPS.  Conversely, tweaks to the ranking algorithms appeared to be mostly ineffective over the long run: after a few months, miscreants manage to adapt to the changes in the ranking systems.

In parallel, we were able to evidence the presence of strong "concentration points." Specifically, we discovered that while the unlicensed sale of pharmaceutical drugs appears to be a rampant plague, it is in fact supported by a very small ecosystem of successful "advertisers" who bring traffic to these online pharmacies. Likewise, there appears to be a very small ecosystem of actual production facilities that provide medicine to most of the pharmacies we found online. And last, there appears to be a strong concentration in the infrastructure used by miscreants (a number of lynchpin servers were all hosted on the same cloud-based facilities). This indicate possible scalable intervention policies worth pursuing.

Perhaps even more importantly, our research also led us to discover that it was possible to proactively discover that a certain website was on the verge of being compromised and enrolled in a questionable advertising campaign. This has opened potentially fruitful avenues for future research on proactive (as opposed to reactive) defenses, before compromises even happen.

We expanded our study beyond search engines, to include economic considerations. Specifically, we tested whether rank manipulation in recommender systems may prime consumers to choose goods that they would not otherwise purchase; We measured the effect of this mechanism on the well-being of consumers finding that firms can manipulate recommender systems in ways that make consumers worse off; and, broadening our horizons beyond search engines, the above was obtained exploring results from a large-scale randomized experiment in a real-world video-on-demand system.

Work done under this award was recognized with publications in top conferences in security and usability, including ACM CCS, USENIX Security, and ACM EC, and working papers to be submitted to policy journals. It resulted in a best student paper award at USENIX Security 2014, and yielded two PhD dissertations. Additionally, this award resulted in substantial successful outreach efforts, including disseminating results to policy makers, such as the White House, or the US Food and Drugs Administration (FDA).
